quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: You're managing a construction project. A vendor offers you expensive tickets to a championship game if you select their bid. Their bid is competitive but not the lowest. Your friend who works for a competing vendor asks you to share the other bids so they can 'sharpen their pencil.' Meanwhile, you discover the previous PM inflated budget estimates to create a secret reserve.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What should you do FIRST?

options.A: Accept the tickets since the bid is competitive anyway
options.B: Decline the tickets, refuse to share bids, and report the budget inflation
options.C: Share the bids with your friend to help them out
options.D: Keep quiet about the budget inflation to avoid causing problems

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Decline the tickets, refuse to share bids, and report the budget inflation

insights.explanation: Take ownership of your decisions. Report unethical behavior even when it's uncomfortable.
insights.pmbokSupport: PMI Code of Ethics: Responsibility means making decisions we can live with and reporting unethical behavior.

insights.explanation: Provide equal access to information. Don't play favorites or accept inappropriate gifts.
insights.pmbokSupport: PMI Code of Ethics: Fairness means making decisions and acting impartially and objectively. Avoid conflicts of interest.

insights.explanation: Be truthful in communications and conduct. Don't conceal wrongdoing.
insights.pmbokSupport: PMI Code of Ethics: Honesty means understanding the truth and acting in a truthful manner in communications and conduct.

insights.explanation: Respect the procurement process and all stakeholders by maintaining integrity.
insights.pmbokSupport: PMI Code of Ethics: Respect means our duty to show consideration for ourselves, others, and resources.

patternRecognition.patternRule: When facing ethical dilemmas, apply all four values: Be Responsible (report it), be Respectful (treat all fairly), be Fair (no favoritism), be Honest (transparent).

coreFramework.frameworkName: RRFH - The PMI Code of Ethics
coreFramework.frameworkIntro: PMI's Code of Ethics has 4 pillars. These aren't just exam topics - they define professional conduct. Think 'RRFH' (Roof - protecting the profession):

rows.action: Take ownership; make decisions we can live with; report violations
keyQuestions: What's the right thing to do?
rows.examKeywords: report violations, take ownership, accountability, escalate, disclose

rows.action: Show consideration for people and resources; listen to others; conduct yourself professionally
keyQuestions: Am I treating people with dignity?
rows.examKeywords: listen, cultural sensitivity, professional conduct, cooperation, dignity

rows.action: Make impartial decisions; avoid conflicts of interest; provide equal access
keyQuestions: Is there a conflict of interest?
rows.examKeywords: impartial, objective, no favoritism, conflict of interest, transparency

rows.action: Be truthful; don't deceive; provide accurate information; admit mistakes
rows.examKeywords: truthful, accurate, transparent, correct errors, no deception

coreFramework.additionalContent:

Responsibility ‚Üí Respect ‚Üí Fairness ‚Üí Honesty

These 4 pillars form the ROOF that protects the project management profession.

‚ö†Ô∏è Exam Critical: Ethics questions have ZERO tolerance. When in doubt, choose the option that: (1) Reports violations, (2) Declines gifts, (3) Maintains transparency, (4) Puts integrity above convenience.

pmbokConnection.quote: As practitioners and representatives of an established profession, we are expected to demonstrate a commitment to ethical and professional conduct.

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: PMI's Code of Ethics applies to ALL PMI members, certification holders, and those applying for certification. Violations can result in certification suspension or revocation.
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: When facing ethical dilemmas: What would be right if everyone could see my decision?
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Ethics questions are often 'easy points' if you remember: Always choose the MOST ethical option, even if it's uncomfortable. Report violations. Decline gifts. Be transparent.
visualReferenceCard.pmbokPrinciple: Stewardship - Demonstrate commitment to ethical and professional conduct

secondScenario.title: Apply the RRFH Framework
secondScenario.intro: Now that you know the framework, let's apply it to a new situation.
secondScenario.scenarioStory: You're managing a software project. A team member tells you confidentially that they inflated their time estimates by 50% to 'build in buffer.' You also discover a competitor's proprietary code in your team's repository. Your sponsor asks you to report that the project is 'on track' even though you're three weeks behind.
secondScenario.question: What's the MOST ethical response?

options.A: Tell the sponsor the truth, address the code violation, and coach the team member on honest estimating
options.B: Report the team member to HR for dishonesty
options.C: Tell the sponsor what they want to hear to avoid conflict
options.D: Ignore the code issue since it's saving time

quotes.text: As practitioners of project management, we are required to conduct ourselves in an ethical manner. The PMI Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct describes the expectations that we have of ourselves and our fellow practitioners.
quotes.author: PMI
quotes.source: PMI Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct

quotes.text: On the exam, ethics questions are designed to be straightforward if you follow one rule: Choose what's RIGHT, not what's EASY. Always report violations. Always decline inappropriate gifts. Always be truthful. There's no gray area in PMI ethics.
quotes.author: PMP Instructor Insight

fieldInsights.title: Real-World Application
fieldInsights.insight: Ethics violations in projects lead to reputation damage, legal issues, and loss of trust. A PM who accepts a gift today loses credibility tomorrow. A PM who conceals problems destroys stakeholder confidence. Your reputation is built on thousands of small ethical choices.

fieldInsights.title: Exam Strategy
fieldInsights.insight: If an ethics question feels tricky, apply this test: 'Would I be comfortable if this decision appeared in tomorrow's newspaper?' If not, it's the wrong choice. PMI expects the HIGHEST standard of conduct, not the minimum.

memoryPalace.title: üèîÔ∏è Memory Palace: The Four Pillars of the Summit Shelter
memoryPalace.intro: At the summit, there's a shelter held up by 4 pillars (RRFH = ROOF). Each pillar represents an ethical value:

story.title: The Summit Shelter's Four Pillars
story.narrative: You've reached the summit! But a storm is coming. The only shelter is a small structure held up by 4 pillars. Each pillar represents one of PMI's ethical values. Remove any pillar, and the entire roof collapses.

scenes.description: The RESPONSIBILITY pillar (painted blue) has an inscription: 'Take Ownership.' This pillar reminds you to make decisions you can live with and REPORT violations. You see a logbook where climbers report safety hazards - that's responsibility in action.

The RESPECT pillar (painted green) shows carved ears - symbolizing LISTENING. This pillar reminds you to show consideration for others, listen to different perspectives, and conduct yourself professionally. Cultural flags from different nations hang from this pillar.

The FAIRNESS pillar (painted orange) has balanced scales carved into it. This pillar reminds you to make IMPARTIAL decisions, avoid conflicts of interest, and provide equal access. A 'No Gifts' sign hangs prominently on this pillar.

The HONESTY pillar (painted purple) is made of transparent crystal - symbolizing TRANSPARENCY. This pillar reminds you to be truthful, provide accurate information, and correct errors. You can see right through it - nothing hidden.

story.moral: The storm rages outside, but the shelter holds strong because ALL FOUR pillars are solid. Remove one - say, accepting a gift (Fairness violation) or concealing a problem (Honesty violation) - and the entire roof collapses. Ethics isn't optional; it's the foundation of the profession.

memoryPalace.selfTest: Close your eyes and stand in the summit shelter. Touch each pillar. Can you recall all 4 ethical values using RRFH?
